subject: Economics
subcategory: Economic Crises That Shook the World
title: The Long-Term Capital Management Collapse
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Long-Term Capital Management Collapse.

hook.text: Two Nobel laureates built a hedge fund with 'risk-free' trading strategies.

buildup.text: LTCM used complex math to find tiny price differences and bet billions on them. Returns were 40% per year.

discovery.text: Russia's 1998 default triggered a global panic. LTCM's 'impossible' losses happened simultaneously across every market.

twist.text: LTCM's positions were so large that its failure would have frozen the global bond market. The Fed organized a $3.

climax.text: LTCM proved that mathematical models can't capture once-in-a-century events.

punchline.text: Two Nobel Prizes in finance couldn't prevent one spectacular failure.

quiz.question: What lesson did LTCM's collapse teach about financial models?
